title: Can I remove my spouse from the title on our home for taxes he owes?
question: I am trying to determine if I am able to remove my spouse from the title on our home for taxes he may owe? Am I able to do that? WOuld this stop IRS from coming into my home and doing a searh and seziure? Can they take my car if only in my name? Can they take his car if in both our names? Thanks for your help
answers: The IRS is a supercreditor with rights that are unavailable to other creditors. One of their most powerful tools is lein rights. If your husband owes tax debts, he could be subject to a lien against the property (more specifically, a "statutory" lien based on 6321 of the Internal Revenue Code). The timing of the lien is tough to beat. It arises when a taxpayer fails to pay any tax after a demand by the IRS for payment. And the lien "relates back” to the date of assessment of the tax, meaning that it is effective from that day forward. So simply transferring property out of his name to yours may not be the best strategy. The IRS lien could still follow the property into your hands.

It sounds like you want to remove him from the title forcibly. That is not going to happen without a court order in a divorce proceeding. As the attorney before mentioned, he could quit claim deed the property over to you, but I don't see why he (or anyone) would voluntarily give up their house. Furthermore, if he quit claim deeded the house to you on the eve of an attempt to collect by the IRS, they could allege that the transfer was a fraudulent conveyance.
You should also be aware that if he owes taxes for years in which you filed jointly, you are liable for those taxes as well.
As far as what the IRS can take.....they are the most powerful creditor in the country and they can take pretty much anything. I strongly suggest you consult with a tax attorney as soon as possible to begin taking steps to solve your apparent tax problems. Doing nothing would not be wise.

The easy answer is to ask your spouse to give you a Quitclaim Deed which puts the house in your name. Generally a spouse won't do that unless you have something he wants. Are you getting a divorce? The judge might order that he sign a Quitclaim Deed or otherwise take him off title. That should hold off the IRS from your house. Have you been married long? Is it a community debt? If it is a community debt and the car is community property, they may be able take the car, however it is registered. Your property is not automatically community property. If you bought it with your premarriage earnings or your inherited property, then it is your separate property.
